factoid: Saying 'on the march' indicates wearing greatcoats.
Michael Mítrich reproachfully told the battalion commander that saying 'on the march' means wearing greatcoats.
Michael Mítrich stepped resolutely forward after exclaiming 'Oh, my God!'.
Michael Mítrich shouted 'Company commanders!' in a commanding voice.
Michael Mítrich shouted 'Sergeants major!' and asked the aide-de-camp how soon he would arrive.
The aide-de-camp answered that the officer would arrive in an hour's time.
Michael Mítrich asked the general whether there would be time to change clothes.
The general replied that he did not know.
The regimental commander ordered the soldiers to change into greatcoats.
The company commanders ran off to their companies.
The sergeants major began bustling while the greatcoats were not in good condition.
The squares that had been in regular order and silent began to sway, stretch, and hum with voices.
Soldiers ran to and fro, throwing up knapsacks, pulling straps over their heads, unstrapping overcoats, and drawing sleeves on with upraised arms.
After half an hour all was again in order, but the squares had become gray instead of black.
The regimental commander walked with jerky steps to the front of the regiment and examined it from a distance.
The regimental commander shouted, 'Whatever is this? This!' and stood still.
The regimental commander shouted, 'Commander of the third company!'
The words passed along the lines, and an adjutant ran to look for the missing officer.
The missing officer appeared from behind his company, trotted awkwardly, and approached the general.
The captain's face showed uneasiness of a schoolboy told to repeat a lesson he had not learned.
Spots appeared on the captain's nose, redness due to intemperance, and his mouth twitched nervously.
The general looked the captain up and down as he approached panting, slackening his pace.
The regimental commander shouted, 'You will soon be dressing your men in petticoats! What is this?' at a soldier in the ranks of the third company wearing a greatcoat of bluish cloth.
The regimental commander said the commander in chief is expected and the soldier had left his place.
The commander of the company pressed two fingers more rigidly to his cap.
The commander of the company said, 'Well, why don't you speak? Whom have you got there dressed up as a Hungarian?'
The commander of the company said, 'Your excellency...'
The commander of the company said, 'But what about your excellency? ... nobody knows.'
The captain said, 'Your excellency, it is the officer Dólokhov, who has been reduced to the ranks.'
The captain asked, 'Has he been degraded into a field marshal, or into a soldier? If a soldier, he should be dressed in regulation uniform like the others.'
The captain said, 'Your excellency, you gave him leave yourself, on the march.'
The regimental commander said, 'Gave him leave? Leave? That's just like you young men.'
The regimental commander said, 'Leave indeed... One says a word to you and you... What?' and added with renewed irritation, 'I beg you to dress your men decently.'
The commander turned to look at the adjutant and directed his jerky steps down the line.
The commander was pleased at his display of anger and walked up to the regiment wishing to find a further excuse for wrath.
The commander snapped at an officer for an unpolished badge, at another because his line was not straight, and reached the third company.
